data.title: Close out 2017 With NYC’s Essential Concert Guide • Dec. 18 – Dec. 31
data.meta_description: A Clear Leader in Entertainment News
data.text:
Des Delgadillo

The Marias at Baby’s All Right | Dec. 18

This relatively new act out of L.A. fashions some sentimental pop that feels like it wafted out of a 70s club on a cloud of smoke and perfume. The duo composes lush tracks ready to become a part of your love life. Get romantic when The Marias come to Baby’s All Right in Brooklyn with special guests The Pheels and Pecas.

Common Kings at Brooklyn Bowl | Dec. 19

Unlike what their name might suggest, the sound this band churns out is anything but common. Rooted in Samoa, Tonga, Fiji and Hawaii, the Cotton Kings blur cultural lines with their soul and reggae-infused rock sound. The quartet just dropped their full-length this year, with myriad top producers contributing to the stirring effort. Vibe to the crew’s upbeat sound when they play the Brooklyn Bowl with Roots of Creation.

Pentatonix at Beacon Theatre | Dec. 19-21

Few things are as closely intertwined as Pentatonix and the holiday season. Whether it’s at a department store, on television or at the Beacon Theatre from Dec. 19-21, the a cappella group’s sounds are being enjoyed almost as much as gingerbread lattes. The group’s tremendous harmonies and festive tunes are all anyone needs to get that last push into the holiday spirit.

Billy Joel at Madison Square Garden | Dec. 20

Let’s not kid ourselves. Every show the piano man performs as part of his historic Madison Square garden residency is beyond magical, but with Christmas just days away from his next show, this one’s bound to be extra special. Expect all his usual great hits with a side of holiday cheer served up by the maestro himself.

Ronnie Spector at City Winery | Dec. 20 + 21

One of the most enduring staples of the famed “girl group” era, Ronnie Spector came to prominence as part of the Ronettes before breaking away from the group and ex-husband Phil Specter to pursue solo avenues. Her history is full of amazing duets with some of the best in the business. Although her voice doesn’t quite pack the same punch of her glory days, she has adapted to a style more conducive to her strengths, and she continues to flourish amid a sea of newcomers. See for yourself when she plays City Winery.

Taylor McFerrin at Good Room | Dec. 21

After contributing to father Bobby Mcferrin’s debut back in the 1980s, Taylor grew to be quite the instrumentalist, incorporating beat-boxing and creative production moves. A fortuitous relationship with Flying Lotus’s Brain Feeder label gave him an outlet for even more creative music that never fails to push the envelope. He’ll keep pushing it in a live setting when he plays Good Room.

Jon Bellion at Terminal 5 | Dec. 21 + 22

Bellion is best known for penning “The Monster,” a beastlike outing in its own right, with the Eminem-Rihanna duet enjoying an extended stay atop the Billboard Hot 100. Since then, Bellion’s been back in the lab, this time taking on his own music, which borrows from r&b and indie rock to create something full of soul and just enough introspection. Don’t miss him when he plays two dates at Terminal 5.

A Darlene Love Christmas at BB King Blues Club | Dec. 21-23

Despite her status as a Rock n Roll Hall of Fame inductee, Love never had the impressive track record of most solo singers, instead often contributing more behind the scenes. Still, her take on holiday favorites never fails to get listeners in the spirit. She has three dates celebrating the spirit of the season when she plays BB King Blues Club.

NGHTMRE at Terminal 5 | Dec. 23

The fresh-faced producer made his live debut in a big way, spinning at the Electric Daisy Carnival in Las Vegas, the Mecca of dance music soirees. It all happened so fast. One minute he lucked out and had one of his tracks played by Skrillex, and the next he was collaborating with Dillon Francis. NGHTMRE’s star’s very much still on the way up. Catch him bringing the grooves to Terminal 5 with Valentino Khan and Justin caruso.

Large Professor at Highline Ballroom | Dec. 26

Originally getting his start with Main Source before creative differences forced a split, Large Professor helped power many albums forward from greats like Eric B. & Rakim. His solo work incorporated what he learned from producing those larger-than-life luminaries. Get hyped to his head-nodding beats when Large Professor plays the Highline Ballroom with the iconic Statik Selektah and Roc Marciano.

The Shivers at Bar Lunatico | Dec. 26

Rock, soul and folk epitomize this staple of New York music, and although the lineup might constantly change, their hard-hitting party dynamic remains the same. Their songs range from warm and bubbly to cool as ice. Don’t get left out in the cold. Catch the Shivers at Bar Lunatico.

Trans-Siberian Orchestra at Prudential Center (Newark) | Dec. 26

A group whose first few studio efforts rang clear with holiday tones hits the Prudential Center just 24 hours removed from the day many of their albums celebrate. It’s also a landmark occasion for the larger-than-life project, with this tour marking their first since the death of founder Paul O’Neill.

The Dillinger Escape Plan at Terminal 5 | Dec. 27

There are few bands as face-melting in their approach as the Dillinger Escape Plan, with frenetic flurries dotting everything they do. But what separates them from another average Joe hardcore band is the technical prowess with which they rage, with every measure precisely calculated before it’s delivered. Bodies will be flying every which way when they play Terminal 5, so prepare yourself. The mighty Mike Patton and God Mother will also be on the bill.

The Felice Brothers at Brooklyn Bowl | Dec. 27

This sonically dazzling quartet of brothers Ian, Simone, and James Felice along with Christmas Clapton make their blend of folk and Americana sound absolutely irresistible. Often driven by accordion, it’s hard not to get lost in the mechanics of every song, that is until the lyrics kick in, making listeners’ brains work just as hard as their grooving bodies. They’ll be bringing all kinds of those grooves to the Brooklyn Bowl on Dec. 27.

Thomas Jack at Output | Dec. 27

One of the leading trop-house pioneers comes to New York for a date at Output. His take on dance music influenced big-name producers including Kygo, and you can hear much of his influence on albums from noteworthy artists like Drake. Feel those uplifting vibes when he touches down in The Big Apple. Just because it’s cold doesn’t mean you won’t be able to feel the sun, especially not when Jack brings his tropical flair.

The White Panda at Irving Plaza | Dec. 27

There’s just so much going on when The White Panda comes to town. The mashup kings put on quite the extravagant live performance, complete with the best effects around and digitally projected panda masks. Plus, what’s not to love about your favorite songs getting the mashup treatment, making for a perfect night of hardcore rug-cutting? Don’t miss them when they come to Irving Plaza.

Phish at Madison Square Garden | Dec. 27-31

The iconic freeform outfit hit MSG for a string of shows that Abbi Abrams herself would be proud of. The group made waves with their emphasis on improvisation, a nod to their jazz routes, while generously throwing heaps of folk influences to boot. Don’t get left out in the cold and catch Phish when they play New York’s entertainment Mecca.

Martin Rev and The Juan Maclean w/ Strange Names at The Bowery Electric | Dec. 28

A musical mastermind whose every album features a new, distinct sound, Martin Rev never fails to impress with his versatility. Couple that with a DJ set from The Juan MacLean, and this is the kind of show to make anyone give a roaring “yippee-ki-yay!”

Matisyahu at Irving Plaza | Dec. 28

Where Matisyahu’s effortlessly flawless flows go, the party is sure to follow. The rapper and beat boxer has been merging his skills with top-notch reggae production for over a decade, and the result is still a staggeringly energetic and sometimes politically wrought barrage of sound.

Talib Kweli DJ set at Brooklyn Bowl | Dec. 28

One of the godfathers of conscious hip-hop takes an unfamiliar spot behind the ones and twos, but one can’t help but expect an explosive performance from the man anyway. With a finger adeptly on the pulse, Kweli’s certainly hip to all the new trends before the casual listener is, so he’s bound to drop some gems on the Brooklyn Bowl masses when he gets to spinning some of 2017’s hottest highlights.

Marcus King Band at Gramercy Theatre | Dec. 28-29

Son of grizzled bluesman Marvin King, young Marcus approaches his music with incredible passion and maturity. You wouldn’t know he’s barely lived two decades with the way he takes charge on record and stage. Get a taste of the greatness that’s to come when he hits the Gramercy Theatre with some special guests.

Mija, GG Magree, Zomboy, Jauz, Zeds Dead, Bro Safari at New York Expo Center | Dec. 29 + 31

RPM’s hosting a pre-New Years Eve party that’s bound to rock harder than anything involving a ball dropping. Get positively lit with the hottest dance acts right now. It’s a night that will rock so hard you won’t know what hit you the next morning.

Lettuce at Brooklyn Bowl | Dec 29 + 31

These funky favorites got their start in New York, endearing themselves to anyone who would give them the time of day until they proved their detractors wrong. There’s so much levity in the way lettuce plays their instruments and dominates the stage. Unlike actual lettuce, this band is anything but bland. Get down when they play the Brooklyn Bowl, and you have two chances to catch them. Don’t miss special guest Jon Scofield.

Flosstradamus at Brooklyn Steel | Dec. 30

The DJ duo turned superstar syndicate brought trap to the masses thanks to their big, gritty beats. The Chicago producers are bringing that sound to New York as part of the lead-up to New Years Eve, so expect chaos when they storm Brooklyn Steel. That chaos will be doubled thanks to a special set from Phantoms.

Sammy Adams at Gramercy Theatre | Dec. 30

Named after Boston’s favorite lager, Sammy Adams injects a boastful attitude into everything he chooses to grace with his flow. His party anthems ingratiate him to a college crowd, and you can bet they’ll be out in full force when he hits the Gramercy Theatre for a rager of an evening. Get there early for Millyz, Farrow and Titus.

Macy Gray at Iridium | Dec. 30 + 31

A unique sense of style and a patented rasp gave Gray a ready-made entryway into the music scene, and she was soon putting her signature spin on jazzy standards while giving music fans a palatable alternative to r&b. Her pop appeal might not be as great as it once was, but she continues fortifying an already sound catalogue with more vocal workouts.

The Budos Band at Knitting Factory | Dec. 31

This winning afro-beat and jazz-funk ensemble might have a lot of moving parts, but sometimes it takes a crowd to bring so much soul. They’re quick to kick it with huge horns and bone-crunching percussion, and they’ve got big plans this new Years Eve. Get down with them when they bring their worldly to the Knitting Factory.

FSOE 500 at Brooklyn Hangar | Dec. 31

Egyptian EDM standouts Aly & Fila bring FSOE 500 to Brooklyn. It’s one of the most happening dance events out there, and it’s just what the doctor ordered for a perfect New Years Eve. Don’t miss dazzling dance acts like Dan Stone, James Diamond, Ferry Tayle, Fady & Mina, M.I.K.E. Push, Monoverse, and so many others.

Gloria Gaynor at Top of the Standard | Dec. 31

The “I Will Survive” architect has empowered more people than anyone can bother to count, but that hasn’t stopped her from hitting the road to empower even more listeners. The disco queen was also instrumental in establishing the blueprint for the modern dance album. The icon herself will take the Top of the Standard by storm on Dec. 31, giving fan a chance to ring in New Years Eve in sublime style.

Gramatik at Terminal 5 | Dec. 31

He may have been born in Slovenia, but Gramatik always had a soul that belonged in Brooklyn. He grew up with an affinity for boom bap hip-hop and a wide array of jazz and funk. So when the DJ finally put together his own sounds, they were full of both those influences. It’s bouncy funk that you can’t help but shake it to. Let him take care of all your dancing needs this New Years Eve when he plays Terminal 5 with Big Wild, Ramzoid and Cobrayama.

John Digweed + Tara Brooks at Output | Dec. 31

Innovative producer and DJ John Digweed has a reputation for marathon DJ sets, some even going upwards of 10 hours in length. More importantly, he was instrumental in ushering the progressive house sound onto a bigger stage. Don’t miss this dance icon when he hits Output along with Tara Brooks.

New Year’s Eve Phantasmagoria ft. Evelyn Evelyn at Brooklyn Bazaar | Dec. 31

An interesting project from Amanda Palmer and Jason Webley, Evelyn Evelyn revolves around conjoined twins who performed in a circus from ages 11-19 until Palmer and Webley helped them record an album. The project is heavy on sweet harmony that goes straight to the heart and soul. For those looking to spend New Years Eve watching something a little more artistic should keep this high on their list of plans. Plus, don’t miss special guests Lacy Rose, Alaina Ferris and Kalan Sherrard.
